I need help identifying a hard drive problem (TOSHIBA MG06ACA800E)
hard drive seems to have a chance of randomly shutting down under load. It's like a forced removal, errors are thrown if I was copying data or if qbittorrent was seeding torrents from it and it disappears from windows explorer

To make it re-appear in uefi and windows I need to re-plug the data cable as switching off PSU is apparently insufficient

torrenting/seeding seems to trigger it more easily

I ran a long generic test with seatools (software) to check for corruption or faults and it passed the test
I don't know how to interpret "smart" data, but it is healthy and I observed no change in values before and after the first incident.
I cannot make sense of windows event viewer logs, a lot of errors there may be ordinary in the course of running an operating system


The first time it happened I thought maybe the sata data cable was bent or angled too much, and that with the case's side panel on, it was oppressing the cable.
but since then I've attached a different data cable from a different sata port on the motherboard to it and it still happens

Now I think it's possible the sata power cables running from the psu are related before I'm going to blame it on windows (horrible broken garbage) and a bad combination of software installed there
As you can see in the image, there is one set of sata power cables attached to two hard drives on the left, the top one is the hard drive with issues

I will try re-positioning the hard drive and running the second set of my psu's power cables to it to see if it changes anything.

If anyone has any idea (including requests to post hardware info using x software etc.) please advise, I'm a technologically illiterate retard.
I also don't want to go to normalfag sites, I need to be able to make questions without sign-up.

thank you.

posts.com:
>>1304486
>switching off PSU is apparently insufficient
As in "fully removing power from it (either by unplugging the PSU or by using the switch on the PSU) doesn't fix it"?
Then you definitely have a dodgy SATA cable, and every replacement you've tried is also dodgy. Logically, it can't be anything else. The drive and the motherboard can't store that kind of state if you're not giving them any power, they both fully reset when power comes back.

>You did refer to the data cables, right?
Yes. Power cable should be obvious because it will complain down the data bus or just not make any noise.

So one of my homework problems is this. There is a star with mass = 10 solar masses. The distances with the log of the density (function of distance) divided by the core density is given in the table of pic related. Here the distance is denoted as r / R where R is the total radius of the star which is 4 times the radius of the sun.

Now I'm supposed to use numerical integration to find the core density, but I'm not entirely sure how to go about it. Any help here?

I've already tried using Runge Kutta 4 by turning the mass equation M = 4/3 * pi * r^3 * rho into dM/dr = 4 * pi * r^2 * rho but then you run into not knowing the core density so you can't compute the mass, which you need for finding the core density. I guess I'm missing something here but IDK how you could solve this knowing that there's practically 3 unknown variables in this equation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1303662
You don't know ρ(r), but you do know ρ(r)/ρ_c. ρ_c is a constant, so just put it in the integral and integrate M/ρ_c = ∫014πr2(ρ(r)/ρ_c)dr, which gives ρ_c = M/∫01…dr.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stellar_core
>The temperature of the core region for a Very Low Mass Star decreases with decreasing mass, while the density increases. For a star with 0.1M, the core temperature is about 5MK while the density is around 500g cm−3.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_core
>(The sun) has a density of 150g/cm3 at the center
It's possible that more massive stars have an even lower density though, and your value is not that far off that it seems improbable. I'd do it myself to double check it for you, but desu copying the whole table seems like a pain. Just make sure your mass checks out, maybe try with a different and simpler method like trapezoidal integration and see if you come to a similar outcome.

Yeah, I just tried it again with some different integration methods (trapezoid included) and the answer for the integral was more or less the same. I guess I'm fucking up on the unit conversions or something.

The answer I found for the integral: 3.096865565202606

This should be in cubic solar radiuses because I made the distance go from 0 to 4 (as the star is only 4 solar radius big)

So that should be 3.096865565202606 * 6.96 * 10^5 km^3 (1 solar radius = 6.96 * 10^5 km)

And if I convert it to cm^3 (1 km^3 = 10^15 cm^3) I get 2.1554*10^21 cm^3 as my answer

And then dividing by the stars mass of 10 solar masses in grams I find 9,228101978 * 10^12 g/cm^3

>>1304358
Toei "revived" Sailor Moon Crystal as badly as possible in order to prevent it from cannibalizing its Pretty Cure series. That's why the animation was barely improved from before with the same looks as the original and then put it online instead of a TV channel.

Toei could do it because it had the right of first refusal. Before the author could go to a different studio and producer group, it must first be offered to Toei. If Toei refused to do it, then the author was free to have some other animation house and producer for it. SM competes for the same customer base that buys Pretty Cure merchandise, but SM has no where near the royalty control that Toei has over Pretty Cure. It therefore is in Toei's financial interest to accept SM and then create it as poorly as possible with minimum exposure as possible while avoiding malfeasance lawsuit from Naoko Takeuchi.

So, Toei first delayed the selection of production house for a year or two before accepting. Then Toei took another 1.5 years of poorly made pre production that was rejected and redone. Then SM was finally made after a lawsuit, but it was drawn and animated not much different than the original. This totally failed to take advantage of modern animation illustration and styling. Toei also didn't allow it to be initially released on TV which competed with Pretty Cure, so it was put online instead.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I know my mother's side of the family has a coat of arms. However I have no clue about my dads, I will have to check with my grandmother. I don't think so but I could be wrong.

My question is, is it historically correct to use either dads or moms side crest?
Or should I only be using my dads side because that is the last name I have (because my moms would be attached to her maiden name, not my last name) if that makes sense.

Or are there historically no "rules" based around this, and people generally just choose whatever, or both if they wish.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are definitely rules both historical and current. There are often current laws too. In some countries it is illegal to use a coat of arms without being the armiger, the person having the legal right to use the arms.

There's no such things as a "family coat of arms". In English tradition arms are awarded to individuals not families and can only ever be used by one person at a time. Even if someone in the past was awarded a coat of arms and that person has the same surname as you there's very, very little chance that you are the armiger.

Historically there are English (British) traditions and various Continental traditions. English tradition is patrilineal. Children use arms based upon their father's but marked with a difference. The eldest son inherits his father's arms. Other sons keep a differenced version or, if their father had several titles, arms that go with the title they inherit. Daughters use a version of their father's arms on a lozenge until married. They wouldn't typically inherit so their children would have no right to their grandfather's arms and would use a version of their father's arms.

Continental arms followed different rules and could get very complicated. Husband and wife might combine arms if both families were powerful enough (and if marriage united their holdings) and children would end up with separate designs on the same shield. If those sons married into sufficiently powerful families arms could be combined again and shields can be covered in dozens of tiny designs.

But I'm going to guess you're a yank of British ancestry. Do whatever the fuck you want. There are no laws about heraldry in your country. I very much doubt you have any right to bear arms under the English, Scottish or Irish Colleges of Arms.

BTW the crest is the bit above the helmet which is itself about the shield. It is neither correct nor appropriate to call an achievement of arms a "crest".

> dads or moms
Possessive apostrophes. You used one. Do try harder.

4channelX is what you want.
The filenames actually look like millisecond unix timestamps, but it's actually a regular (second-based) unix timestamp + 3 random numbers.
>really can't tell why some genius decided to make it random numbers what are we a fucking robot??
Be fucking grateful they are not UUIDs (which are the number 1 popular primary key meme in 2k22) because when you save those, they are literally in random order. Unix timestamps encode the datetime, so the older the file, the smaller the timestamp.

Hello frens! I know this sounds weird, but I'm looking for recommendations of completed/finished anime that meet the following criteria:
>Finished airing
Self-explanatory. The show's over.
>Covers ALL of the source material
Some anime have finished airing (like WataMote) but it only ran for a season or so and the manga is still going, so it's just a "tease" at this point.
>Fateful to the source material with next to no fillers
Stuff like Naturo is packed with fillers and whatnot, and some anime are very different from the manga/light novel.

I think a few examples of the stuff I'm searching for would be Death Note, FMA: Brotherhood, Another, etc. Stuff that started as an anime (like Cowboy Bebop) also counts.

Thanks in advance and sorry for the long post!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There's a lot of good original anime, depending on your tastes.
Probably the biggest original anime (that isn't that old) off the top of my head would be
Neon Genesis Evangelion
Code Geass
Gurren Lagann
Puella Magi Madoka Magica
There's other popular originals like Kill la Kill, but I haven't that one personally.
In terms of adaptations of things, some visual novels have popular anime based on them, like Steins;Gate (which I have seen and enjoyed) and Higurashi (which I have not seen but am currently playing).
For anime based on manga, JoJo is always a popular choice, which isn't actually 100% adapted, but each part is its own self-contained story with some shit showing up from previous parts. The Part 6 anime ended just a bit ago, and that's basically the end of the story, since Part 7 was a reboot of sorts
